title.narrative: Covid19 Emergency Response Nepal (CERN) 2021

description.narrative:
Poor and marginalized population, hard to reach communities, vulnerable and People with special needs.
Total Direct beneficiaries – 46, 089 persons (740,000 indirect beneficiaries)

The first case of COVID-19 in Nepal was reported on 23rd January 2020 and nation-wide lockdown was imposed by the Government of Nepal (GoN) on 24th March 2020 to control the possible spread of COVID-19. On 21st July 2020 GoN decided to end nation-wide lockdown limiting mobility of people and public gatherings. Second wave of COVID-19 started on 7th April 2021 and as of 24th May 2021, a total of 6,531 deaths, 520,461 confirmed cases and 115,447 active cases have been recorded. Government of Nepal has called localized strict prohibitory orders to break the infection chain from 29th April 2021 midnight and as of now 75 districts (out of 77 districts) are under lockdown situation.
Nepal now has among the highest viral reproduction rates in the world. The positivity rate, which is highest in the globe at this moment, is hovering around 40% nationally. Hospitals are already overwhelmed with some of the hospitals in the capital has already announced that they are not able to take in new patients since their capacities are now exhausted. Nepal is on the brink of a humanitarian crisis, which is likely to go for at least another two to three months, according to experts. The Nepal government, through its Ministry of Health (MoHP) has issued a request to international development partners to support the government efforts towards providing treatment to the covid patients since the government capacity has almost been exhausted. A list of around 40 immediate medical items needed have been listed and most urgent ones are related to life saving equipment and supplies around improving oxygen production and distribution, together with the medical materials used everyday to test and treat patients.
Together with the emergency supplies, Nepal urgently needs COVID vaccines in order to make a meaningful impact on saving lives. As of 7th May, 2021, only 1.3% of the population have received two dozes of the vaccine and only 7.2% have received first doze and with India deep in crisis, it is unlikely that Nepal will receive more vaccines from India, which was previously its primary source. At this moment, Nepal is undergoing the second wave of COVID19 spread. From other countries, it can easily be said that there are more waves to come. Timely action will save hundreds of thousands of people from unnecessary suffering and death and reduce the long-term impacts of poverty and lost development.
To support the vulnerable communities, health institutions and frontline health service providers in the targeted areas to respond to COVID crisis

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Health - Project Specific

Humanitarian Aid Corporate Indicators
The humanitarian response was Appropriate

description.narrative: Appropriateness is assessed according to the SPHERE standards. A response is considered to be appropriateness based on needs assessment, taking account of rights, needs, culture, age, gender, disabilities and context, and equity (non-discrimination and equal access.

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
